settings.heading: How much sleep is ideal?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
The average person needs 7 to 9 hours of sleep every night, though as we age we often require slightly less sleep. For example, people aged 65+ typically only need 7-8 hours of sleep.

Life events, such as pregnancy, will require individuals to increase the amount of sleep they get to approximately 8 - 10 hours per night, especially in the first trimester.

settings.heading: What are the symptoms of sleep deprivation?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
• Yawning
  • Grogginess in the morning and throughout the day 
  • Brain Fog
  • Dozing off during activities 
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability

settings.heading: What causes sleep deprivation and sleeplessness?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Sleep disorders: Sleep disorders such as insomnia and sleep apneoa affect an individual's ability to get a full night's rest. It's important to work with your doctor to best address these sleep conditions so that you can improve your quality of sleep.

Personal habits: Being a night-owl, socializing until quite late, or drinking coffee after dinner are just a few examples of personal habits that can affect your quality of sleep and contribute to sleep deprivation. If you feel your habits are impacting your quality of sleep, it may be time to make some changes.

Illness: It can be challenging to sleep when you're congested, have a cold or flu, or cough. As you recover from your cold, your sleep schedule should return to normal. If you are struggling to recover from your cold or flu then we recommend visiting your doctor so that they can look into the best steps to alleviate your symptoms and address the root of the problem, as you may require medication or care.

Work: Challenging work schedules can negatively affect your sleep and sleep cycles. If you're required to do shift work, night shifts, or are required frequently to travel then you may find yourself feeling more tired and sleep deprived.

Stress and Anxiety: Feeling overwhelmed, stressed, and anxious often affects sleep. As thoughts or concerns keep you up late at night, you may notice yourself experiencing sleep deprivation symptoms during the day. We recommend you speak to a doctor or a mental health care professional to begin learning best practices to deal with stress and anxiety.

Becoming a new parent: New parents are often quite sleep deprived as they undertake a new schedule of caring, feeding, and comforting a new addition to their family. This typically resolves itself over time as you and your baby establish feeding and care routines, and as the baby grows and is able to sleep for longer periods of time between feedings. (Are you a new parent experiencing postpartum hair loss? If so, we recommend you read this next!)

settings.heading: What does lack of sleep do to the brain and body?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Lack of sleeps means that the brain and body does not get the necessary amount of time to heal itself before starting the next day. This means that mentally and physically, you will not be able to perform at your optimal level. Short term this means you may experience a number of negative side effects such as:

  • Not feeling alert
  • Sleepiness and grogginess throughout the day
  • Headache 
  • Memory difficulty
  • Irritability
  • Difficulty completing normal daily tasks
  • Impaired and dangerous driving

Some studies have shown that sleep deprivation can cause brain fog and block the brain's ability to communicate on a cellular level. This can lead to memory lapses, difficulty concentrating, and even visual disturbances. Over time, as sleep deprivation continues it can cause more serious symptoms which we will discuss next.

settings.heading: Can lack of sleep be serious?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: Yes. Chronic sleep deprivation can impact an individual's health in multiple negative ways. It can contribute to high blood pressure, heart attack, heart failure, diabetes, and stroke. It can also lead to weight fluctuation and weight gain, depression, anxiety, low libido, and impaired immune system function. Chronic sleep deprivation has also been linked to neurological disorders such as Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia.

settings.heading: Can lack of sleep cause hair loss?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: Yes. Sleep deprivation negatively affects recovery processes in the body. When the body cannot heal and recharge properly, there can be significant consequences to the body and bodily functions and those can result in hair loss. Lack of sleep also is linked to higher levels of stress which also can contribute to thinning hair and increased hair fall.

settings.heading: Is hair loss caused that is caused by sleep deprivation permanent?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Typically, hair loss caused by sleep deprivation is reversible. Once your sleep schedule returns to a healthy routine, and any underlying health issues are addressed (which may be caused by sleep deprivation, or cause the sleep deprivation), hair growth cycles typically resume as normal.

If you feel your health has been negatively impacted by your sleep schedule we recommend that you speak directly to your doctor. They will be able to investigate any possible underlying conditions that may be linked to your sleeplessness.
